intro: Alectra pubescens, commonly known as the pubescent bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Campanulaceae family, characterized by its bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, open habitats such as meadows and stream banks. Its leaves are hairy and lance-shaped, and its flowers are usually blue or purple in color. Alectra pubescens is often found in mountainous regions and is adapted to cool, temperate climates.
